facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 19, 1959, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1299 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated March 19,1959, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1299 of 1957.

facts.text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered on January 25, 1962 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. January 25. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-

facts.text: Sankatha Singh and others are the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Sankatha Singh and others appeal against the order of the Allahabad High Court

facts.text: Allahabad High Court dismissed the appellants' application for revision.

anchor.surface_text: dismissing their application for revision of the order of the Sessions Judge, Gyanpur, holding the order of his predecessor for the rehearing of an appeal

facts.text: Sessions Judge, Gyanpur held the order for rehearing to be ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: holding the order of his predecessor for the rehearing of an appeal which had been dismissed earlier to be ultra vires and without jurisdiction

facts.text: Appellants convicted by the Magistrate, I Class, Gyanpur, of offences under ss. 452 and 323 read with s.34, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were companyvicted by the Magistrate, I Class, Gyanpur, of offences under ss. 452 and 323 read with s.34, I.P.C.

facts.text: Kharpattu, one of the appellants, was also convicted of an offence under s. 324, I.P.C.

anchor.surface_text: Kharpattu, one of the appellants, was also companyvicted of an offence under s. 324, I.P.C. They appealed against their companyviction.

facts.text: The appeal was fixed for hearing on November 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was fixed for hearing on November 30, 1956. On that date, neither the appellants number

facts.text: On November 30, 1956, neither the appellants nor their counsel appeared in Court.

anchor.surface_text: On that date, neither the appellants number their companynsel appeared in Court and the learned Sessions Judge dismissed the appeal.

facts.text: Sessions Judge dismissed the appeal on November 30, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and the learned Sessions Judge dismissed the appeal. The relevant portion of his order is The appellants have been absent,

facts.text: Sessions Judge perused the judgment of the Magistrate and the record and found no ground for interference.

anchor.surface_text: I have perused the judgment of the learned Magistrate and seen the record. I find numberground for any interference.

facts.text: Application for restoration presented on December 17, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On December 17, 1956, an application was presented by the appellants praying that the case be restored

facts.text: Appellants claimed they reached late due to ekka overturning and injuries.

anchor.surface_text: In explaining their absence from Court on the date of hearing, it was said that they reached the Court somewhat late due to the Ekka,

facts.text: Application allowed on July 2, 1957 by Sessions Judge Sri Tej Pal Singh.

anchor.surface_text: This application was allowed, on July 2, 1957, by the learned Sessions Judge, Sri Tej Pal Singh,

facts.text: Sri Tripathi succeeded Sri Tej Pal Singh as Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Tripathi, who succeeded Sri Tej Pal Singh as Sessions Judge, and before whom the appeal was put up

facts.text: Sri Tripathi held the order dated July 2, 1957 ultra vires and without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: was of the opinion that the appellate Court had numberpower to review or restore an appeal which had been disposed of and that therefore the order of his predecessor dated July 2, 1957, was ultra vires

facts.text: Appellants filed revision to Allahabad High Court in Criminal Revision No. 1299 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order, the appellants went in revision to the High Court. The learned Judge of the High Court agreed

facts.text: High Court dismissed the revision application.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge of the High Court agreed with the views of Sri Tripathi and accordingly, dismissed the revision application.

issues.text: whether Sri Tej Pal Singh could set aside his first order dated November 30, 1956, dismissing the appeal, when neither the appellants nor their counsel appeared and could order the re-hearing of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: The sole point for determination in this appeal is whether Sri Tej Pal Singh could set aside his first order dated November 30, 1956, dismissing the appeal, when neither the appellants nor their counsel appeared and could order the re- hearing of the appeal.

issues.text: whether a criminal appeal can be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel

anchor.surface_text: A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel. The Court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal to enable them to appear, or should consider the appeal on merits and pass the final order.

issues.text: whether the Sessions Judge considered the merits of the appeal

anchor.surface_text: Sri Tej Pal Singh was aware of this as his order itself indicates. He did not dismiss the appeal for default. He himself perused the judgment of the Magistrate and the record and did consider the merits, as he says in his order I find no ground for any interference.

issues.text: whether omission to write a detailed judgment gives power to the judge to set it aside himself

anchor.surface_text: provisions of s. 367 of the Code and may be liable to be set aside by a superior Court, but will not give him any power to set it aside himself, and re-hear the appeal.

issues.text: whether s. 423 requires the appellate court to hear the appellant or pleader regardless of appearance

anchor.surface_text: s. 423 of the Code enjoined the appellate Court to dispose of the appeal after hearing the appellant or his pleaders. If none of these appears at the hearing, the appellate Court can proceed with the disposal of the appeal on merits.

issues.text: whether notice under s.422 must be given to both appellant and pleader

anchor.surface_text: s.422, Cr. P. C. were also not fulfilled, as no notice was ever issued to the appellant. He again missed noticing that a notice of the hearing of the appeal has to be given either to the appellant or to his pleader and need not be given to both.

issues.text: whether inherent powers can be exercised to order re-hearing when prohibited by s.369 and s.424

anchor.surface_text: in the exercise of the inherent powers which every Court possesses in order to further the ends of justice ... Inherent powers cannot be exercised to do what the Code specifically prohibits the Court from doing.

issues.text: whether the successor Sessions Judge was competent to consider the validity of the predecessor's restoration order

anchor.surface_text: Sri Tripathi was competent to consider when the other party raised the objection whether the appeal was validly up for re-hearing before him. He considered the question and decided it rightly.

anchor.surface_text: s. 369, of the Code definitely prohibited the Courts reviewing or altering its judgment, he had no jurisdiction to consider the point raised and to set aside the order dismissing the appeal and order its re- hearing.

holdings.text: Sri Tej Pal Singh could not set aside his first order dated November 30, 1956, dismissing the appeal, when neither the appellants nor their counsel appeared and could order the re-hearing of the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that he could not do so and that therefore the view taken by the High Court is correct. A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal properly dismissed on merits after perusal; no power to review under s.369; s.423 allows disposal if no appearance.

holdings.text: A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel. The Court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal to enable them to appear, or should consider the appeal on merits and pass the final order.

anchor.surface_text: A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel. The Court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal to enable them to appear, or should consider the appeal on merits and pass the final order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mandatory duty under s.423 to decide on merits if no appearance, not dismiss for default.

holdings.text: Sri Tej Pal Singh did consider the merits of the appeal as he perused the judgment and record and found no ground for interference.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Tej Pal Singh was aware of this as his order itself indicates. He did not dismiss the appeal for default. He himself perused the judgment of the Magistrate and the record and did consider the merits,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order text shows perusal and consideration, not default dismissal.

holdings.text: Omission to write a detailed judgment may not be in compliance with s.367 but does not give power to set it aside himself and re-hear the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: His omission to write a detailed judgment in the circumstances may be not in compliance with the provisions of s. 367 of the Code and may be liable to be set aside by a superior Court, but will not give him any power to set it aside himself,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Non-compliance challengeable by superior court only, no self-review.

holdings.text: s.423 does not require hearing the appellant or pleader if none appears; appellate court can proceed on merits.

anchor.surface_text: He omitted to notice the words 'if he appears' after the expression and hearing the appellant or his pleaders. If none of these appears at the hearing, the appellate Court can proceed with the disposal of the appeal on merits.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.423 proviso 'if he appears'.

holdings.text: Notice under s.422 need be given to either appellant or pleader, not both.

anchor.surface_text: a notice of the hearing of the appeal has to be given either to the appellant or to his pleader and need not be given to both.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain language of s.422; usual practice to counsel.

holdings.text: Inherent powers cannot be exercised to review or restore appeal when prohibited by s.369 read with s.424.

anchor.surface_text: Inherent powers cannot be exercised to do what the Code specifically prohibits the Court from doing.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific statutory prohibition overrides inherent powers.

holdings.text: Successor Sessions Judge (Sri Tripathi) competent to consider validity of predecessor's restoration order when objected by other party.

anchor.surface_text: Sri Tripathi was competent to consider when the other party raised the objection whether the appeal was validly up for re-hearing before him. He considered the question and decided it rightly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction to determine if appeal properly before him.

holdings.text: Sessions Judge had jurisdiction to dispose of restoration application but no jurisdiction to set aside dismissal order under s.369.

anchor.surface_text: He certainly had jurisdiction to dispose of the application presented to him, but when s. 369, of the Code definitely prohibited the Courts reviewing or altering its judgment, he had no jurisdiction to consider the point raised and to set aside the order dismissing the appeal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited jurisdiction to receive application, but barred from review by s.369.

holdings.text: Section 369 read with s.424 prohibits appellate court from altering or reviewing judgment once signed, except clerical error.

anchor.surface_text: Section 369, read with s. 424, of the Code, makes it clear that the appellate Court is not to alter or review the judgment once signed, except for the purpose of correcting a clerical error.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual interpretation confirming no review power.

anchor.surface_text: We are of opinion that he could not do so and that therefore the view taken by the High Court is correct. A criminal appeal cannot be dismissed for the default of the appellants or their counsel. The Court has either to adjourn the hearing of the appeal to enable them to appear, or should consider the appeal on merits and pass the final order.
